author: By Asher Elbein
title: How 2 Pterosaurs’ Last Meals Ended Up in the Fossil Record
description: Paleontologists in China found pellets of undigested food — just like ones owls leave behind — preserved with pterosaur fossils.
content: Fur, bones, feathers and scales can be murder on the digestion. So predators that gulp their prey down whole face a conundrum: What do you do with the indigestible bits? Owls and other birds of prey cough up anything unusable. If you’ve been to a science museum, you may have dissected one of the products of these digestive outbursts, known as owl pellets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich, Makiko Inoue and Shiho Fukada
title: ‘A Sense of Crisis’ for Wasabi, a Pungent Staple of Japanese Cuisine
description: Climate and demographic threats are chipping away at a centuries-old culture surrounding the cultivation of the fluorescent green plant.
content: IZU, Japan — For three decades, Mitsuyasu Asada has proudly tended the same lush mountainside terraces where his father and grandfather grew wasabi, the horseradish-like plant with a fluorescent green hue and head-clearing pungency that unmistakably connotes Japanese cuisine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz, Alyssa Lukpat and Jesus Jiménez
title: Manhunt Continues for Gunman Who Killed 1 at Grocery Store in Washington State
description: A gunman opened fire inside a Fred Meyer supermarket in Richland, Wash., on Monday morning, killing one person and critically injuring a second, the authorities said.
content: A manhunt continued late Monday for a gunman who the police say killed one person and critically injured another person  at a grocery store in Richland, Wash., that morning, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Rodrigues
title: A Photographer’s View of Jordan’s Many Splendors
description: For 10 days, a photojournalist drove across Jordan from north to south, visiting several of the country’s most treasured sites. Here’s what he saw.
content: In September 2021, after more than two years without traveling, my girlfriend and I decided to take a trip to Jordan — mainly to see the ancient city of Petra.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: How to Make the Best Meringues
description: Melissa Clark has tips to yield results that are sure to impress. Let her set you up for success.
content: Humble and mysterious, an unbroken egg is “one of the most private things in the world,” the food writer M.F.K. Fisher wrote. But once cracked open, it reveals itself to be a flamboyant shape-shifter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Frontier and Spirit Airlines Plan to Merge
description: The budget carriers said they would save customers $1 billion a year while adding jobs.
content: Spirit Airlines and Frontier Airlines, two prominent budget carriers, on Monday announced plans to merge, a combination that would create the fifth-largest U.S. airline by market share, putting pressure on the nation’s biggest carriers and raising concerns about further consolidation in an already-concentrated industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: As Baseball Fights Over the Short Term, Long-Term Problems Loom
description: Arguments over the sport’s financial structure could delay or shorten the season, but owners and players should address a bigger issue: improving the product.
content: The saddest part about the baseball lockout, which almost certainly will delay the start of spring training and perhaps trim the regular season, is the missed opportunity. Again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: President Biden adopts steps for promoting union membership.
description: Many of the recommendations, proposed by a White House task force, would make it easier for federal workers and employees of contractors to unionize.
content: The White House on Monday released a report outlining several dozen steps it intends to take to promote union membership and collective bargaining among both public and private sector employees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Marr
title: The Brutal Truth of Boris Johnson’s Conservative Party
description: This may be a British story, but the Conservatives’ decision on Johnson’s fate will resonate among many political parties across the democratic world.
content: LONDON — British Conservatives, who have ruled the country for longer than any other party in recent history, are in an agonized, self-flagellating panic. Should they get rid of Boris Johnson, their populist leader, whose deceit and breaking of lockdown rules have infuriated so much of the country and embarrassed his party? Or stick with a man who, so far, has kept them in power?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikita Richardson
title: How The Sims Became the Internet’s Most Exciting Place to Eat
description: The 22-year-old life-simulation video game has evolved into a world where players can farm, forage, cook and learn about the many ways people experience food.
content: In the last year, Kayla Sims began raising her own cows and chickens. She did a bit of traveling, trying dishes like bhel puri, tuna maki rolls, beef yakisoba and feijoada for the first time. She even did some cooking; one day, she made a crown roast and baked a birthday cake shaped like a hamburger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arthur Lubow
title: The Art World’s Amazing Spider Man
description: Tomás Saraceno’s creations, including those on view at a new exhibition at the Shed, lie at the intersection of sculpture, ecology and futuristic experimentation.
content: TOMÁS SARACENO’S STUDIO, in a gritty eastern district of Berlin, stands on toxic ground. After more than a century of industrial use, the land was saturated with contaminants. When Saraceno took over the derelict brick building in 2012, the sale came with restrictions. “They said, ‘Please don’t plant apple trees near the street,’” he recalled, because “‘people will eat an apple and be poisoned.’”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Snickers, Slights and Stamina: Rise of a Speedskating Legend
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, February 7, 2022.
content: “He’s the king of speedskating. And I’m maybe a little bit the queen.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Producer of ‘The Matrix Resurrections’ sues Warner Bros. over how the film was released.
description: The suit by Village Roadshow claims Warner Bros. rushed the release of the movie to help boost HBO Max subscriptions, a revenue stream Village Roadshow doesn’t share in.
content: The film production and financing company Village Roadshow filed a lawsuit on Monday against Warner Bros. Entertainment, a longtime partner, saying the studio engaged in “deliberate and consistent coordinated efforts” to reduce the value of Village Roadshow’s intellectual property by releasing “The Matrix Resurrections” simultaneously in theaters and on the streaming service HBO Max.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.2 Million Homes in California
description: A Spanish-style home in Los Angeles, a Craftsman cottage in St. Helena and a midcentury ranch house in Redwood City.
content: View Park, added to the National Register of Historic Places in 2016, is one of the largest historic districts in California, with its well-kept 1920s and 1930s homes. This house, a contributing property to the historic district, is about half a mile from Crenshaw Boulevard, one of the area’s major thoroughfares. Downtown Los Angeles is about 20 minutes away, depending on traffic; Culver City is about a 15-minute drive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Dispute Over Test Results Hints at Lingering Mistrust of Russia
description: A game between Canada and a Russian team was delayed by 65 minutes because of “safety and security concerns.” When it started, the players all wore masks.
content: Follow our latest coverage of the 2022 Winter Olympics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Weight, Well-Being and a Champion’s Absence From the Games
description: Maren Lundby’s decision to skip the ski-jumping season, and the Beijing Olympics, started a conversation about mental health in Norway.
content: Not too long ago, Maren Lundby seemed a lock for a gold medal at the 2022 Winter Olympics. Lundby, 27, a ski jumper from Norway, had won gold at the 2018 Games in Pyeongchang, South Korea; three straight World Cup titles, from 2018 to 2020; and gold medals in the 2019 and 2021 World Championships.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Fisher
title: A Moment for Canada’s Far Right, Still Struggling for Support
description: The country’s political system has made it hard for fringe groups to gain influence. But a new cause, and fund-raising across borders, could begin to fuel Canadian populists.
content: The truck convoy protests in Ottawa and several provincial capitals represent an unexpected show of strength for the far right and populist right factions at their helm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Jessica Cheung, Sydney Harper, Lisa Tobin, Chris Wood, Chelsea Daniel and Marion Lozano
title: Who Else Is Culpable in George Floyd’s Death?
description: Derek Chauvin was sentenced to 22 and a half years for the murder, but what about the other officers who were at the scene?
content: Almost two years ago, a shocking nine-minute video was released showing a Minneapolis police officer, Derek Chauvin, fatally kneeling on the neck of George Floyd.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Athletes take to social media to give fans a view from inside the bubble.
description: Olympians’ videos provide glimpses of food, accommodations, Covid tests and the frigid weather in Beijing.
content: Olympic athletes are just like us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Republicans, Wooing Trump Voters, Make Fauci Their Boogeyman
description: G.O.P. candidates, tapping into voters’ frustrations with a seemingly endless pandemic, are stepping up their attacks on Dr. Anthony S. Fauci.
content: COLUMBUS, Ohio — When Jane Timken kicked off an eight-week advertising campaign on the Fox News Channel in her bid for the Republican nomination for Senate, she did not focus on immigration, health care or the economy. Her first ad was titled “Fire Fauci.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: They Made Millions on Luna, Solana and Polygon: Crypto’s Boom Beyond Bitcoin
description: The ranks of cryptocurrency speculators have swelled, with even obscure tokens minting the newly wealthy: at least on the blockchain.
content: Etienne vantKruys, a globe-trotting cryptocurrency investor from Amsterdam, was hunting for a new investment two summers ago when he met some early backers of Luna, a digital coin that offers a framework for decentralized finance. Impressed by their commitment to the project, he bought $25,000 of Luna for 20 to 35 cents a coin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Macron tries to mediate the Ukraine crisis.
content: The standoff with Russia over Ukraine is at a critical point. The U.S. has snapped NATO to attention and moved forces east, while Moscow has readied still more soldiers on the Ukraine border. But beneath those tensions, diplomatic avenues are being feverishly explored and the outlines of potential solutions, still amorphous, may be taking form.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Dutch Soccer Star Steps Down After Admitting to Inappropriate Texts
description: Marc Overmars, a former player who became a director at Ajax, one of Europe’s top clubs, apologized for his actions. The club said he had “gone over the line.”
content: Marc Overmars, a former Dutch soccer star who became a top executive at one of Europe’s most prominent teams, has abruptly left his job after admitting to sending inappropriate text messages to female colleagues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen
title: A Democrat takes over the F.D.I.C. after a partisan clash.
description: Martin J. Gruenberg replaced Jelena McWilliams, a Trump appointee who stepped down after a conflict with Mr. Gruenberg and two other Democratic members on the board.
content: A Democratic bank regulator, Martin J. Gruenberg, has taken the helm at the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation after a partisan fight prompted his Republican predecessor to resign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Alan Yuhas
title: Town Called Itself a Big Cat Habitat to Block Housing, Then Reversed Course
description: A Silicon Valley town declared itself a mountain lion habitat to forestall duplexes on small lots. Facing ridicule and the threat of legal action, officials backed down.
content: For most of a two-hour meeting last month, the leaders of a wealthy Silicon Valley town debated a new state law that vexed them: Senate Bill 9, allowing developers to build duplexes on single-family lots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Beat Feuz wins the men’s downhill by a tenth of a second.
description: The giant slalom and the downhill take place on different slopes and with different skiers.
content: Beat Feuz of Switzerland, a brawny downhill specialist whose career was threatened by a serious knee injury a decade ago, won the Olympic men’s downhill on Monday at the National Alpine Ski Center in Yanqing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval and J. David Goodman
title: ‘Errors’ at Treatment Plant Force 1 Million in Austin to Boil Their Water
description: It is the second time in a year that residents of the Texas capital have been told to boil water before drinking.
content: AUSTIN, Texas — Roughly one million people in Austin have had to boil their water since Saturday after officials said “errors” at a treatment plant resulted in potentially unsafe water flowing into homes and businesses in one of the largest and fastest-growing American cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: A Digital Archive of Black Fashion Delves Into Print
description: Black Fashion Fair is releasing a new publication featuring photography, essays and more ahead of New York Fashion Week.
content: Black Fashion Fair, a digital directory of Black designers started by Antoine Gregory, is taking its project to print.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: That Sigh You Hear Is the Sound of Danger Escaping From Risky Sports
description: Increasingly, competitive snowboarders and freeskiers are practicing their aerial tricks by landing on cushy airbags instead of hard snow. Purists wonder: Where’s the sport in that?
content: Follow our latest coverage of the 2022 Winter Olympics
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill McKibben and Akaya Windwood
title: Call It ‘Codger Power.’ We’re Older and Fighting for a Better America.
description: We don’t want to leave the world a worse place than we found it.
content: Neil Young and Joni Mitchell did more than go after Spotify for spreading Covid disinformation last week. They also, inadvertently, signaled what could turn out to be an extraordinarily important revival: of an older generation fully rejoining the fight for a working future.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Feb. 7, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Feb. 7, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Wong
title: He Survived the Holocaust and Was Killed Crossing the Street at Age 99
description: Jack Mikulincer was on his way to synagogue to observe the Sabbath when he was hit by an SUV in Brooklyn, the police and family members said.
content: After surviving two wars, the Nazi invasion of Hungary and the Holocaust, a 99-year-old man died Saturday afternoon after being hit by a car on his way to synagogue, family members and the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: At the Winter Olympics, hard tricks and even harder falls.
description: They fell on the snow and they fell on the ice. They fell on flat tracks and steep hills. They fell on their backs and their hips and, most jarringly, at least one fell going as fast as she could.
content: They fell on the snow and they fell on the ice. They fell on flat tracks and steep hills. They fell on their backs and their hips and, most jarringly, at least one fell going as fast as she could.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Booster Problem
description: Why are Americans slow to get booster shots?
content: The United States has a vaccination problem. And it is not just about the relatively large share of Americans who have refused to get a shot. The U.S. also trails many other countries in the share of vaccinated people who have received a booster shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Indigenous Ingredients and Inspired Baking Mastery, at Gusto Bread
description: A modern panadería in Long Beach, Calif., is challenging the idea of Eurocentric authority in the fine pastry realm.
content: LONG BEACH, Calif. — The pleasure of a well-made kouign-amann — a French pastry from the town of Douarnenez, perfected in bakeries across Brittany — is in that tickle of salty butter layered throughout the laminated roll, set against the sweetness of the yeasted dough and the dark caramel that covers it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Swedish sisters Hanna and Elvira Oberg fail to medal.
description: The Swedish press has been buzzing about the medal chances for the duo.
content: When Hanna Oberg won a gold medal in the biathlon for Sweden in 2018, it was the first for the country’s women in 12 years. She seemed to establish herself as her nation’s best hope for more medals in the years to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Putin and Macron Meet
description: The French president said Europe was at a “crossroads.”
content: President Emmanuel Macron of France said that Europe was at a “critical crossroads” as he met in Moscow with President Vladimir Putin of Russia. In Washington, President Biden met with Germany’s new chancellor, Olaf Scholz, to discuss Russia’s military buildup at Ukraine’s borders. Here are the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: Did Eric Adams, an Avowed Vegan, Eat Fish? (Yes, and It Was No Fluke.)
description: The mayor has highlighted his plant-based diet. Now he has acknowledged that he is “imperfect” and has told the “food police” to back off.
content: For much of his recent public life, Mayor Eric Adams has loudly proclaimed that he loves salads, beets, lentils and green smoothies and that transforming his diet has changed his life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Biden says a Russia-to-Germany pipeline would not go forward if Moscow invades Ukraine.
description: After meeting with the German chancellor, Mr. Biden promised a united response to Russia.
content: WASHINGTON — After meeting with the leader of Germany, President Biden said on Monday that a lucrative gas pipeline project connecting Russia and Germany would not go forward if Moscow were to invade Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: When the Storming of the Capitol Becomes ‘Legitimate Political Discourse’
description: This is one of those weeks when it feels  we are doomed to permanent craziness.
content: Gail Collins: Hey, Bret, the new jobs report looked pretty good. Would you say Joe Biden is starting off the Winter Olympics season with a triple salchow?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: U.S. broadcast coverage includes curling and luge.
description: The first run of the women’s singles luge event will air at 8:05 a.m. on USA Network.
content: U.S. broadcast coverage of the 2022 Winter Games in the early morning hours on Monday. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: The Legalized Gambling Free-for-All
description: We seem to have dropped any pretense of responsible wagering.
content: In math class in high school, my friends and I would gamble on a card game called Tunk. Our teacher, a nice young man whom we gently ignored, was too overwhelmed by the demands of his job to pay much attention to the budding degenerates in the back of the classroom. Our school had just opened a Taco Bell stand in the cafeteria. My friends and I did not have much money at the time, so we resorted to gambling with our classmates for taco funds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
title: Israel to Investigate Domestic Use of Pegasus Spyware as Scrutiny Hits Home
description: The decision reflected rising concerns about the use of the spyware in Israel, and could affect the corruption trial of former Prime Minister Netanyahu.
content: JERUSALEM — The intensifying scrutiny of NSO Group, the Israeli spyware firm, has largely come from overseas as evidence mounted that authoritarian governments had used NSO products to spy on political opponents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac and Mike Isaac
title: Peter Thiel to Exit Meta’s Board to Support Trump-Aligned Candidates
description: The tech billionaire, who has been on the board of the company formerly known as Facebook since 2005, is backing numerous politicians in the midterm elections.
content: Peter Thiel, one of the longest-serving board members of Meta, the parent of Facebook, plans to step down, the company said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: N.J. Governor to End School Mask Mandate in Move to ‘Normalcy’
description: For the first time since the start of the pandemic, New Jersey districts will be permitted to allow students and teachers to stop wearing masks.
content: Gov. Philip D. Murphy of New Jersey, a Democrat who has imposed some of the nation’s most stringent pandemic-related mandates, will no longer require students and school employees to wear masks, signaling a deliberate shift toward treating the coronavirus as a part of daily life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Max Parrot of Canada wins gold in men’s snowboard slopestyle.
description: Su Yiming of China won the silver, and Mark McMorris, the top rider of the past decade, came in third.
content: The slopestyle course at Genting Snow Park in Zhangjiakou has received mostly rave reviews for its difficulty and its Great Wall-themed design. On Monday, its centuries-old evocation, made of snow, served as a stage for some next-era acrobatics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: U.S. prime-time broadcast coverage on Monday includes figure skating, hockey and skiing.
description: The figure skating rivals Nathan Chen and Yuzuru Hanyu go head-to-head in the men’s short program at 8:15 p.m.
content: [Follow our live Men’s Figure Skating updates from the Winter Olympics.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia and Saskia Solomon
title: Royal Nod for ‘Queen Camilla’ Caps Years of Image Repair
description: Queen Elizabeth II has put to rest decades of speculation by giving Prince Charles’ wife, Camilla, what some see as her “stamp of approval.”
content: LONDON — The title “queen” looms large in the British public consciousness, never more so than during the rule of the nation’s longest-serving monarch, Queen Elizabeth II.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin and John Branch
title: Eileen Gu, chasing the first of three golds for China, qualifies for the big air final.
description: The freeskier from California announced in 2019 that she would ski for China after a couple of seasons competing for the United States.
content: Eileen Gu, the 18-year-old freeskier from California who hopes to win three gold medals for China, her mother’s home country, has advanced to the final of big air, her first Olympic event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lawrence Ulrich
title: Lucid Air: A Fresh Face With 500 Miles to a Charge, and Horsepower to Spare
description: Chasing Tesla, companies like Lucid are finding that starting an E.V. from scratch has its advantages. A comparison with Mercedes-Benz’s new EQS shows how.
content: Legacy automakers, facing years of unkind comparisons with a boom-timey Tesla, have fallen back on a defensive refrain: Just you wait.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Looking for Early Warning Signs of Pancreatic Cancer
description: Scientists are exploring whether the onset of diabetes may in some cases herald the existence of one of the most deadly of all cancers.
content: Pancreatic cancer is a nasty, stubborn killer that has thus far defied medicine’s best efforts at early diagnosis and curative treatment. In November, it claimed the life of my friend Peter L. Zimroth, a 78-year-old New York City attorney who was devoted to public service and who most recently oversaw the decline in the police department’s stop-and-frisk strategy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bakalar
title: Chimps Catch Insects to Put on Wounds. Is It Folk Medicine?
description: They don’t eat the bugs, and they’re definitely applying them to wounds, so some scientists think the primates may be treating one another’s injuries.
content: Chimpanzees design and use tools. That is well known. But is it possible that they also use medicines to treat their own and others’ injuries? A new report suggests they do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Coffee Grown in the Shadow of Volcanoes
description: The roasting company Volcanica Coffee offers more than 100 coffees from dozens of locations where volcanoes loom.
content: In regions where coffee is grown in mineral-rich volcanic soil, the complexity of the beans receives a boost. Volcanica Coffee, a roasting company based in Suwanee, Ga., focuses on just that, with more than 100 mostly single-origin coffees from dozens of locations around the world where volcanoes loom. It recently introduced several so-called “natural” coffees, processed by sun-drying instead of the more typical washing, which can increase the depth of flavor. Their Ethiopia Natural is alluring, scented of blueberries, and the Costa Rica Natural is full-bodied and chocolaty. The company has also added several gift assortments for Valentine’s Day (on sale until Feb. 28, $59.99 for two coffees, 16 ounces each, with mugs). The family-owned company, founded in 2004, donates one percent of retail sales to charity:water, an organization that supports projects to provide clean drinking water in developing countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Cake Stands
description: Because you might want to bake a cake for Valentine’s Day.
content: If you plan to bake a cake for someone on Valentine’s Day — or any other time of the year, for that matter — a great cake stand will make it look even more impressive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: unavailing
description: This word has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word unavailing has appeared in four articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 27 in the book review “Jonathan Franzen’s ‘Crossroads,’ a Mellow, ’70s-Era Heartbreaker That Starts a Trilogy” by Dwight Garner:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeriya Safronova
title: Is Confidence the Secret to Success? Not Exactly.
description: Shani Orgad and Rosalind Gill discuss their book, “Confidence Culture,” which challenges the idea sold to women that self-esteem will set them free.
content: Several years ago, Shani Orgad and Rosalind Gill noticed that a common message was being sent to women through advertisements, self-help books, music and other media: The solution to all their problems was to be more confident.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: The Super Bowl and an Oscar Micheaux Documentary
description: The Super Bowl airs on NBC. And TCM airs a documentary about a pathbreaking filmmaker.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Feb. 7-Feb. 13. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Spiers
title: What We Lose When Work Gets Too Casual
description: The pandemic has eroded many of the formalities of white-collar work — changes that may benefit employers more than their employees.
content: Like so many with a desk job, I’ve spent the pandemic working from home — or more specifically, the bed in a bedroom of our microscopic Brooklyn apartment, which also houses a 6-year-old, a cat named James Bond and a Roomba named DB5. When I have Zooms for work, I try to put on something that passes for business casual and make sure my hair doesn’t look like I’ve been spending my free time in the local wind tunnel. But strictly speaking, this effort may be unnecessary because many of the formalities of the white-collar workplace have eroded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: ‘We Need to Talk About Cosby.’ (Among Others.)
description: W. Kamau Bell’s documentary series is a model of how to engage honestly with disgraced artists and their art.
content: There is a simple, amazing thing that W. Kamau Bell does in his Showtime documentary series, “We Need to Talk About Cosby.” While interviewing subjects about the comedian and actor accused of multiple rapes, Bell has them watch scenes of Cosby’s performances on a tablet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron DePasquale
title: An Omicron subvariant gains in Europe, but is unlikely to alter the picture very much, experts say.
description: Though the BA.2 subvariant spreads more readily, it does not appear to cause more serious disease than the BA.1 version of Omicron, the coronavirus variant that drove the latest global surge.
content: A subvariant that scientists believe is even more contagious than the most common form of Omicron is spreading rapidly in parts of Asia and Europe and is now dominant in Denmark, where nearly all Covid restrictions were lifted last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: The Magic of Meringues
description: Don’t be intimidated by this marvel of food science: It’s much easier than you think to get the lofty egg whites of your dreams. Melissa Clark explains.
content: There are few transformations in cooking as miraculous as turning an egg into a meringue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Peng Shuai, the Chinese tennis player, meets the I.O.C. leader in Beijing.
description: Peng largely disappeared from public life after making sexual abuse allegations against a powerful political official.
content: Peng Shuai, the Chinese tennis player who largely disappeared from public life after making sexual abuse accusations against a political official in November, held a private meeting with Thomas Bach, the president of the International Olympic Committee, in Beijing over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Free Community College Is Off the Table, Jill Biden Says
description: In a speech on Monday, the first lady acknowledged that her signature legislative initiative is “no longer” in the Democrats’ spending bill.
content: WASHINGTON — During his first address to Congress last spring, President Biden said that Jill Biden, the first lady, would lead an effort to fulfill his administration’s promise to provide two years of free community college to all eligible students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: A dispute over virus testing suggests a lingering mistrust of Russia.
description: Although Canadian officials avoided accusing their Russian counterparts of misconduct, they had reason for concern.
content: The concern showed up most obviously in the masks, the ones suddenly worn on the benches, by the referees and, remarkably, by the women playing Olympic hockey in Beijing on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Your Favorite Fast Food Is Probably From California
description: A large share of the nation’s most popular restaurant chains started in the Golden State.
content: GLENDALE, Calif. — In a quiet corner of the Glendale Galleria shopping mall, between a video game store and a pizza place, a red sign glows “Panda Express.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: Oh Deer!
description: Scientists are worried about outbreaks among white-tailed deer.
content: Even as cases of the coronavirus in the U.S. are declining among humans, scientists are getting worried about outbreaks among wild animals — particularly in the country’s enormous population of white-tailed deer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Markoff
title: Tiny Chips, Big Headaches
description: As the largest computer networks continue to grow, some engineers fear that their smallest components could prove to be an Achilles’ heel.
content: Imagine for a moment that the millions of computer chips inside the servers that power the largest data centers in the world had rare, almost undetectable flaws. And the only way to find the flaws was to throw those chips at giant computing problems that would have been unthinkable just a decade ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: Syria’s Kurds Wanted Autonomy. They Got an Endless War.
description: The Kurds of northeastern Syria dreamed of establishing an autonomous, multiethnic and gender-equal utopia. Instead, their breakaway region has been engulfed in conflict since its creation.
content: QAMISHLI, Syria — Suad Shukri arrived early one morning last week to visit her son’s grave. An hour later, the small cemetery would be thronged by thousands of mourners burying 12 fighters from a Kurdish-led force who were killed battling the recent Islamic State attack on a prison in northeast Syria.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: In Tennessee, the ‘Maus’ Controversy Is the Least of Our Worries
description: The new bans are a response to contemporary political forces whose true motivation has nothing to do with books.
content: NASHVILLE — Tennessee school boards, you may have heard, have been busy lately striking long-beloved, award-winning classic literature from their social studies and language arts curriculums. The Williamson County School Board recently took a hard look at more than 30 texts, restricting the use of seven and striking one altogether: “Walk Two Moons,” a Newbery Medal-winning, middle-grade book by Sharon Creech that follows the story of a 13-year-old girl whose mother is missing. According to the group Moms for Liberty, who lodged the formal “reconsideration request” that caused the school board to take up the issue, “Walk Two Moons” is inappropriate for fourth-grade readers because it features “stick figures hanging, cursing and miscarriage, hysterectomy/stillborn and screaming during labor.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: A Slip and a Slow Start Cost Two Stars Alpine Gold
description: Mikaela Shiffrin tumbled and was disqualified from the giant slalom. Hours later, the favorite in the downhill, Aleksander Aamodt Kilde, finished fifth.
content: YANQING, China — Every Olympics delivers its own crushing surprises: the ill-timed injury, a star figure skater’s tumble to the ice, a mental mistake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘What We Know About Unfolding the James Webb Space Telescope’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about the history and journey of the most powerful observatory in space and what it might discover. Then, they will research a question of their own about the universe.
content: Featured Article: “What We Know About Unfolding the James Webb Space Telescope” by Joey Roulette and Dennis Overbye
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren McCarthy
title: The sprint before the Games: A U.S. speedskater sidelined by Covid tests is on his way to Beijing.
description: Casey Dawson, who already missed the 5,000-meter race, is hoping to land hours before the 1,500-meter event takes place, if all goes according to plan.
content: Casey Dawson, a 21-year-old speedskater for the United States, is on his way to Beijing after testing requirements kept him in Salt Lake City as the Games got underway last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: How the Deaths of N.Y.P.D. Officers Have Shaped Eric Adams
description: The mayor’s views on policing are tied in part to his relationships with families of officers killed on the job, as well as with police abuse victims.
content: In his final days before taking office, Mayor Eric Adams made an unheralded visit to a Brooklyn church for a memorial service honoring two police officers killed in the line of duty seven years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Kenneth H. Brown, Playwright Best Known for ‘The Brig,’ Dies at 85
description: He drew on his own experiences in the Marines to depict brutality within the corps, drawing acclaim Off Off Broadway.
content: Kenneth H. Brown, a New York playwright whose acclaimed 1963 Off Off Broadway play “The Brig,” based on his experiences as a Marine, portrayed dehumanization inside a military prison during the Korean War, died on Feb. 5 at a hospice in Queens. He was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: What Do You Think About Efforts to Ban Books From School Libraries?
description: Parents, activists, school board officials and lawmakers around the country are challenging books about race, gender and sexuality at a pace not seen in decades. What is your reaction?
content: Please note: Our Student Opinion questions specifically invite the voices of young people. We ask that adults respect the intent of this forum and refrain from posting here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Heart-Shaped Croissant From Ladurée
description: The Paris-based bakery, confectioner and restaurant is offering this flaky Valentine on its own and as part of a holiday package.
content: Heart-shaped everything — bagels, pizza, cheese and even Dutch ovens — is the Valentine’s Day signature. Now Ladurée, the Paris-based bakery, confectioner and restaurant, has created its first heart-shaped croissant, a generous, properly flaky beauty with a ruby glaze and nubbins of rose. It will be sold at the pastry counter in the bakery’s New York locations in SoHo and on the Upper East Side, $5 (and $5.50 at the restaurant). It is also part of a Valentines breakfast package for two alongside pains au chocolat, macarons with Valentine messages, and rose lattes made with beets and rose powder, $40, available for pickup through Monday. The pastries demand to be eaten fresh; advance ordering is recommended.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Ditch the Dessert Wine for This Levain Cookie Beer
description: The Brooklyn-based Talea Beer has joined with Levain Bakery to create a stout brewed with dark chocolate chip cookies.
content: Here comes another pandemic Valentine’s Day. According to a study conducted in January among just over one thousand adults by the data company Morning Consult, only 43 percent of the sample plans dinner out, down from 69 percent in 2017, the last time the study was run. (The reason most often given was the virus, not inflation.) So if you are planning an intimate evening at home, get creative with what to drink alongside dessert: cookie beer. Talea Beer, based in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, has joined with Levain Bakery to create an almost ebony stout brewed with their popular dark chocolate chip cookies and cocoa in the mash. The beer is more bitter than sweet with a mouth-filling richness, and is quite strong at 8.5 percent A.B.V. (alcohol by volume). The sumptuously dense, gooey cookie, or any other chocolate dessert for that matter, is better than a pretzel with this beer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The History of Hercules Posey, ‘The General’s Cook’
description: Ramin Ganeshram, of the Westport Museum for History and Culture in Connecticut, will discuss the life of the enslaved chef of George Washington.
content: Those who have watched the series “High on the Hog: How African American Cuisine Transformed America” on Netflix will know the name Hercules Posey, the enslaved Black chef who set a high standard for George Washington’s table in Philadelphia, and later cooked as a free man in New York City. Ramin Ganeshram, the executive director of the Westport Museum for History and Culture in Connecticut, has studied the life of Mr. Posey and will discuss it at a virtual Zoom meeting of the Culinary Historians of New York. She also made it a subject of a novel, “The General’s Cook,” but her talk will reveal new research.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: How Failure Forced Canada Into a Curling Reckoning
description: “You can’t just slap a maple leaf on your back and be guaranteed a medal anymore,” one Canadian said.
content: Disappointed. Demoralized. Dejected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Home Depot Worker Swapped $387,500 in Fake Bills for Real Ones, Officials Say
description: The U.S. Secret Service said Adrian Jean Pineda bought prop $100 bills, which are used for entertainment purposes, and swapped them for genuine currency for four years.
content: Adrian Jean Pineda had an entry-level job at a Home Depot in 2018, working as a vault associate in Tempe, Ariz., in charge of counting the money from registers, placing it in sealed bags and depositing it at a local Wells Fargo Bank.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: Short-Track Speedskating: How It Works and Who’s Worth Watching
description: Long-track speedskating is all about grace and efficiency. Short track is often about chaos.
content: BEIJING — The first night of short-track speedskating at the Olympics did not disappoint. The hosts China won their first gold medal of the Games, the U.S. mixed relay team was disqualified, and there were Olympic records and exciting races aplenty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Dufort and Suzanne Koller
title: Spring’s Most Surreal Fashion
description: Whether defined by color, shine or body-altering shape, this season’s boldest pieces bring the promise of transformation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Water Supplies From Glaciers May Peak Sooner Than Anticipated
description: New satellite mapping of the world’s mountain ice suggests Earth’s glaciers may contain less water than previously thought.
content: The world’s glaciers may contain less water than previously believed, a new study has found, suggesting that freshwater supplies could peak sooner than anticipated for millions of people worldwide who depend on glacial melt for drinking water, crop irrigation and everyday use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Keh
title: Ireen Wüst becomes the first person to win individual golds at five Olympics.
description: The Dutch speedskater, 35, set an Olympic record in the 1,500 meters, then said she would retire.
content: Ireen Wüst of the Netherlands threw her hands above her head after finishing her 1,500-meter speedskating race on Monday. It was a great time, and she knew it: 1 minute 53.28 seconds, a new Olympic record.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: From Connecticut to California, officials announce the easing of mask orders.
description: As new Covid cases continue to recede, states are taking a closer look at their pandemic restrictions.
content: Connecticut will permit students and staff members to stop wearing masks in schools by no later than Feb. 28, after Gov. Ned Lamont recommended Monday that the statewide mask mandate end on that date.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes and Sabrina Imbler
title: Is the Coronavirus in Your Backyard?
description: White-tailed deer could become a reservoir for the virus, putting people and animals at risk, health experts say.
content: In late 2020, the coronavirus silently stalked Iowa’s white-tailed deer. The virus infected large bucks and leggy yearlings. It infiltrated a game preserve in the southeastern corner of the state and popped up in free-ranging deer from Sioux City to Dubuque.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir and Faiz Abubakar Muhamed
title: ‘Democracy Is Life’: The Grass-Roots Movement Taking On Sudan’s Generals
description: Hundreds of loosely connected “resistance committees” are organizing nonviolent protests, tracking the injured and dead and demanding a government led by civilians.
content: KHARTOUM, Sudan — In a bare, dusty field in a neighborhood north of the Sudanese capital, Khartoum, about a hundred people — gray-haired men in white robes and turbans, young women in jeans and T-shirts, mothers with their children in tow — gathered on a recent evening to discuss what they see as their nation’s most pressing need: democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The New Frontier in Antitrust Fights?
description: A proposed union of budget airlines could test competition policy.
content: Frontier Airlines said today it plans to buy a rival budget airline, Spirit, for $2.9 billion in stock and cash. The companies pledged that merging would create jobs and save consumers money, but the deal is almost sure to draw tough scrutiny from the Biden administration’s emboldened antitrust enforcers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Lee Myers and Amy Qin
title: Both Sides of Taiwan Strait Are Closely Watching Ukraine’s Crisis
description: Taiwan knows what it’s like to have an overbearing neighbor. China wonders how forcefully Western powers might react to a Russian invasion.
content: BEIJING — With Russia massing troops along Ukraine’s borders, President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan felt compelled to act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Barbara
title: The Brazilian President’s Latest Sabotage Efforts Have Failed
description: Jair Bolsonaro tried to undermine vaccination for kids. Luckily for Brazilians, it didn’t work.
content: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Every day, I have the same wish: that my 3½ -year-old daughter can get her Covid-19 vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Alvin Kamara Charged With Felony Battery After Nightclub Altercation
description: The star running back for the New Orleans Saints was accused of being involved in a fight the day before the Pro Bowl but was not taken into custody until after playing in the exhibition game.
content: Alvin Kamara, the New Orleans Saints’ star running back, was arrested on Sunday afternoon in Las Vegas for a felony charge of battery resulting in substantial bodily harm, according to a statement from the Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department. He was released from the Clark County Detention Center later that day after posting a $5,000 bond, and his next court date is scheduled for March 8, according to a jail official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Black Country, New Road’s Perilous Triumph
description: The British band’s second album, “Ants From Up There,” arrived days after its primary lyricist, Isaac Wood, announced his departure from the group.
content: On Jan. 31, four days before the British band Black Country, New Road released its second album, “Ants From Up There,” its vocalist and lead guitarist, Isaac Wood, suddenly announced he was leaving the group, with a statement suggesting mental health struggles. “I have been feeling sad and afraid too,” Wood announced via social media. “I have tried to make this not true but it is the kind of sad and afraid feeling that makes it hard to play guitar and sing at the same time.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen, Ivan Nechepurenko, Aurelien Breeden, Shashank Bengali and Anton Troianovski
title: Macron meets Putin in Moscow, aiming for a de-escalation.
description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, who has positioned himself at the center of Europe’s furious diplomatic maneuvering over Ukraine, said on Monday that the continent was at a “critical crossroads” as he met in Moscow with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
content: President Emmanuel Macron of France, who has positioned himself at the center of Europe’s furious diplomatic maneuvering over Ukraine, said on Monday that the continent was at a “critical crossroads” as he met in Moscow with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise
title: Amazon doubles its cap on base salaries for corporate employees.
description: Citing a competitive labor market, the online retailer raised the cap on cash compensation for salaried workers to $350,000, from $160,000.
content: Amazon has told its corporate employees that it is raising its cap on base cash compensation to $350,000, more than double the previous amount, citing “a particularly competitive labor market,” according to an internal announcement viewed by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: The Goal Is to Go Fast. Just Not Too Fast.
description: Technology and safety are colliding in sliding sports, where sleds made for speed are finding tracks built to slow them down.
content: Follow our latest coverage of the 2022 Winter Olympics
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Who are the protesters and what do they want?
description: The demonstrators are a diverse collection of people animated by fatigue over pandemic restrictions, seeking something that is not in the federal government’s power to grant.
content: The demonstrations shaking the nation’s capital began as a protest against the mandatory vaccination of truck drivers crossing the U.S.-Canada border. They have morphed into a battle cry against pandemic restrictions as a whole, and the leadership of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: How Instagram, FedEx and Wordle Hook You
description: The brand architect Debbie Millman says it’s all about design.
content: Brands like Gucci, Nike and Ralph Lauren are already flooding virtual worlds like Roblox and Fortnite with digital goods and advertising. But the designer and podcaster Debbie Millman thinks these emergent virtual worlds run the risk of the same problems many see with social media platforms like Instagram — particularly if users are put in environments that lend themselves to comparison. “I don’t know very many people that come away from 30 minutes on Instagram feeling really good about who they are,” says Millman. And she’s not bullish about web 3.0 solving the problem: “That experience in A.R., V.R. is going to ultimately have the same thing happen.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Thousands Remain Without Power in Tennessee After Winter Storm
description: Schools in the Memphis area were closed on Monday after an ice storm last week led to widespread power failures.
content: Thousands remained without power and schools were closed on Monday in parts of Tennessee in the aftermath of an ice storm last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Are You Ready to ‘Live With’ the Coronavirus?
description: We’re asking readers about plans for their post-Omicron lives and what “living with the virus” means to them.
content: A growing number of governments, politicians and top health officials are saying it’s time to start “living with the virus.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Qin and Chris Buckley
title: Criticism of Zhu Yi, a U.S.-born skater, shows the harsh scrutiny of naturalized athletes in China.
description: Social media users began deriding Zhu on Sunday, after she fell during the women’s singles short program.
content: [Follow our live coverage of Nathan Chen and Yuzuru Hanyu at the Winter Olympics.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Tesla faces renewed scrutiny over racial bias and Elon Musk’s tweets.
description: The electric carmaker disclosed the new legal issues in its annual report to securities regulators, which was made public on Monday.
content: Tesla is facing fresh scrutiny from federal and state regulators about its chief executive’s social media posts and allegations of discrimination at its California factory, the company revealed in a securities filing that was made public on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: The U.S. and Japan strike a deal to roll back Trump-era steel tariffs.
description: The agreement will transform a current 25 percent tariff into a so-called tariff-rate quota, exempting up to 1.25 million metric tons of Japanese steel.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration reached a deal to partly lift tariffs that the Trump administration had imposed on Japanese steel, agreeing to scale back levies that had rankled both the Japanese government and American manufacturers that use imported metal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel
title: Canada convoy draws online support from far-right activists around the world.
description: Prominent figures in numerous countries, including the U.S., Australia and Germany, have praised the protests, spreading the images and arguments widely.
content: The truck convoy protests in Canada that have roiled the nation’s capital are attracting support online among far-right activists across the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Stop Calling Them ‘Accidents’
description: A forthcoming book argues many so-called accidents are due to neglect of the poor and vulnerable.
content: Unintentional injuries happen all the time. Cars crash, people fall off ladders, houses burn down when candles catch the drapes on fire. So, what could Jessie Singer possibly mean when she says “there are no accidents”?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amal El-Mohtar
title: A Gamer Learns to Weaponize Sounds in This Genre-Bender
description: Our latest science-fiction and fantasy column includes “Battle of the Linguist Mages,” “In the Serpent’s Wake” and “The Violence.”
content: Scotto Moore’s BATTLE OF THE LINGUIST MAGES (Tordotcom, 441 pp., $28.99) is absolutely wild, a wacky dance battle of a book with a wry, grounding edge. Isobel Baillie has devoted the last eight years of her life to being queen of the video game Sparkle Dungeon, a rave-themed virtual-reality dungeon crawler and its three sequels, topping the leaderboards at the cost of her job and her girlfriend. But her notoriety leads to an opportunity with the game’s ad agency, Jenning & Reece. On the pretext of performing usability testing for Sparkle Dungeon 5, she is taught “power morphemes” — ways to condense layers of meaning into abstract sounds that can bend real-world physics, shattering glass and folding space-time. Her teachers call these “combat linguistics,” but the titular linguist mages — including politicians, cult leaders and gaming executives — have competing ends in mind, and Isobel is instrumental to all of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Turkey’s Doctors Are Leaving, the Latest Casualty of Spiraling Inflation
description: Doctors, worn down by grueling hours and violence, are emigrating in rising numbers, undermining one of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s signature achievements.
content: ISTANBUL — Anxiety rose after an assistant doctor died last fall when she plowed her car into the back of a truck after a long shift.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: During a bumpy first few days, Covid’s shadow looms as a Russian figure skater shines.
description: The Winter Olympics are heating up — and not always in the best of ways.
content: The Winter Olympics are heating up — and not always in the best of ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Rosenthal
title: Polio, Chickenpox, Measles … Covid-19? The Case for Vaccine Mandates in Schools.
description: Requiring children to get vaccinated for Covid is controversial. We should consider it anyway.
content: The rapid spread of Omicron across the nation — and the finding that vaccines continue to provide strong protection against severe disease — brings Covid-19 one step closer, perhaps, to truly earning its place on the list of diseases that have been tamed by vaccines. These include polio, measles, mumps, rubella,and chickenpox, all of which most kids must generally be vaccinated against before they enter school or day care. Some states have announced Covid vaccine requirements for some students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Desiree Ibekwe
title: David Olusoga Wants Britain to Face Its Past. All of It.
description: For more than a decade, the historian and broadcaster’s work has focused on bringing his country’s uglier histories to light. Recently, more people are paying attention.
content: LONDON — In December, when a British court cleared four Black Lives Matter protesters of criminal damages for toppling the statue of Edward Colston, a 17th-century slave trader, in June 2020, it was thanks in part to David Olusoga’s expert testimony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Kashmir Hill
title: I.R.S. to End Use of Facial Recognition for Identity Verification
description: After a bipartisan backlash, the agency will transition away from using a service from ID.me.
content: WASHINGTON — The Internal Revenue Service plans to stop using facial recognition software to identify taxpayers seeking access to their accounts on the agency’s website amid concerns over privacy and data security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: The Wine Business Sees a Problem: Millennials Aren’t Drinking Enough
description: As baby boomers retire and buy less wine, producers need new ways to tempt a White Claw generation back from other alcoholic drinks, according to a new report.
content: The American wine industry believes it has a problem: millennials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: The Tsunami Could Kill Thousands. Can They Build an Escape?
description: A major quake in the Pacific Northwest, expected sooner or later, will most likely create waves big enough to wipe out entire towns. Evacuation towers may be the only hope, if they ever get built.
content: OCEAN SHORES, Wash. — The 350 children at Ocean Shores Elementary School have practiced their earthquake survival plans, dropping under desks to ride out the convulsions, then racing upstairs to the second floor to await the coming tsunami.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: A Henry Darger Dispute: Who Inherits the Rights to a Loner’s Genius?
description: Since this reclusive artist died in 1973, his landlords have controlled work left behind in his apartment. Now relatives are challenging that stewardship in court.
content: When the janitor-turned-artist Henry Darger died in Chicago at 81 in 1973, leaving a single room crammed with his colorful illustrations, a 15,000-page book and no immediate surviving relatives, Darger’s landlord began showing, sharing and selling his work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Spanish Sausages for the Big Game
description: For those that grill in any weather: Cúrate Bar de Tapas, a Spanish restaurant in Asheville, N.C., has a new site filled with specialties.
content: In search of sausages for the Bengals vs. the Rams? Cúrate Bar de Tapas, a Spanish restaurant in Asheville, N.C., has added an online marketplace for nationwide shipping; sausages are a specialty. They have assembled a package of their own deliciously meaty butifarra, rich morcilla casera, spicy chorizo and ruddy, spiraled chistorra ($65). Sear the sausages and slice them into thick coins to toothpick on a platter for game day. Also from the restaurant’s own kitchen are sauces, including tomate fresco for that out of season pan con tomate, and a lovely Basque-style goat cheese cake with a typical burnt topping ($28). The market also sells Spanish imports, including red prawns, rice, fresh pork, cured ham and olive oil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joy Dong
title: Two years after his death, the Chinese doctor who warned of the virus is remembered.
description: Social media users flocked to an online profile for Dr. Li Wenliang, who provided an early warning about the coronavirus in 2019.
content: Two years after the death of Li Wenliang, the doctor who tried to warn China about the coronavirus only to succumb to it himself, his memory remains a source of equal parts grief, anger and hope for many Chinese.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Precious Fondren
title: Fire Erupts at Brooklyn Building Under Construction
description: No serious injuries were reported, a New York Fire Department spokesman said on Monday. It was unclear whether residents in nearby buildings were required to evacuate.
content: More than 130 firefighters responded to a fire at a building under construction that collapsed in Brooklyn on Monday, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Restores Alabama Voting Map That a Court Said Hurt Black Voters
description: A special three-judge court had ordered lawmakers to redraw the lines, saying Black voters “have less opportunity” than other Alabamians to elect their favored candidates.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday reinstated an Alabama congressional map that a lower court had said diluted the power of Black voters, suggesting that the court was poised to become more skeptical of challenges to voting maps based on claims of race discrimination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Whet Moser
title: Germany, Mask Mandates, Olympics: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Ending the School Mask Mandate in N.J. and Studying Wastewater in N.Y.
description: Gov. Philip Murphy is expected to allow school districts to permit students and teachers to go without masks.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll check the latest developments on several fronts in the coronavirus pandemic, starting with an announcement about mask requirements in schools that is expected today from Gov. Philip Murphy of New Jersey. We’ll also see why New York City weathered the Omicron variant and hear about viral fragments with only-in-New York patterns of mutations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: ‘Pure Colour’ Seeks Answers About Love, Mortality and God
description: In Sheila Heti’s new novel, a young woman considers the state of civilization and briefly joins her dead father on another plane of existence.
content: Sheila Heti’s new novel, “Pure Colour,” is about a young woman who turns into a leaf. “Unrequited love’s a bore,” Billie Holiday sang. So, it turns out, is photosynthesis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: This ‘Phony Negroni’ Is Bitter but Not Boozy
description: The Brooklyn distiller St. Agrestis is offering a nonalcoholic version of the classic.
content: Louis Catizone, an owner of the Brooklyn distiller St. Agrestis, has entered the busy nonalcoholic field with a drink that gets right to the point: the phony negroni. The garnet-red drink comes in the same conical bottle as the company’s well-made spirited negroni and has the same herb and citrus formula. It retains the bitterness you’d expect, but it’s a trifle sweet and, of course, lacks buzz. The differences can be partly overcome by adding a generous squirt of fresh blood orange juice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen and Dan Bilefsky
title: Ottawa Mayor Declares State of Emergency Amid Antigovernment Protests
description: A 10-day demonstration by truckers and other protesters has ensnarled Canada’s capital and led officials to warn that things could turn violent.
content: Follow our latest coverage of the trucker protests in Canada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Billions’ Season 6, Episode 3 Recap: Street Fighting Man
description: Prince forms an unsavory alliance to help make a giant land grab. Chuck grabs a bullhorn.
content: “I look at every competitor as a potential partner … right up until I can’t anymore.” As far as one-sentence encapsulations of the Mike Prince Method go, it’s hard to beat this statement by the billionaire coprotagonist of the sixth season of “Billions.” In this week’s episode, titled “S.T.D.” (it’s not what you think), Prince drives one such competitor — one of the more odious figures in the “Billions” legendarium — to the edge of defeat, then rides in to save his bacon and enrich them both.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: Crypto and the Power of Folk Economics
description: When we think we understand something, we don’t see a reason to regulate it.
content: This week, we continue our discussion about speculative financial technologies, specifically those that run on the blockchain: cryptocurrency and non-fungible tokens. Since I started writing about such technologies last month, it feels that my crypto marketing has picked up significantly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: With Little New Competition, ‘Encanto’ Is No. 1 a Fourth Time
description: The soundtrack to Disney’s latest animated film holds at the top of Billboard’s album chart in its 10th week out.
content: Disney’s “Encanto” soundtrack, with songs by Lin-Manuel Miranda, tops the Billboard album chart for a fourth time this week, with no major new releases to challenge it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Day in Falls
description: Sometimes the Olympics are about success. Sometimes they’re about the other side of it.

description: We spent the day with Ukrainian soldiers on the front lines of the conflict with Russia-backed separatists near the southeast border with Russia.

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Ottawa Declares State of Emergency Over Trucker-Led Protests
description: The mayor of Ottawa declared the state of emergency after more than a week of unrest that began with protests by truckers over vaccine mandates. Demonstrations have spread beyond Canada’s capital.
content: The mayor of Ottawa declared the state of emergency after more than a week of unrest that began with protests by truckers over vaccine mandates. Demonstrations have spread beyond Canada’s capital.

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Spotify Stands by Joe Rogan: ‘Canceling Voices Is a Slippery Slope’
description: In a memo following Rogan’s apology for past use of a racial slur, Spotify’s chief executive said the company would invest $100 million in audio “from historically marginalized groups.”
content: Spotify is not canceling Joe Rogan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: On game birds, grilled portobellos and more recipes for the week ahead.
content: Good morning. I flushed a ruffed grouse out of a snow-covered field in the Maine woods a while back, and the image of it flying — exploding into the sky, then banking toward a stand of aspen — has stuck with me since. You may know the ruffed grouse as a partridge, may have eaten one in the home of a hunter (mild, sweet meat), may even have seen a Meissen-style porcelain depiction sitting on a starched white tablecloth at a fancy dinner party.
source.name: The New York Times
